clinical_study.brief_title: Non-invasive Estimation of CSF Pressure Using MRI in Patients With Spontaneous Intracranial Hypotension
clinical_study.official_title: Non-invasive Estimation of CSF Pressure Using MRI in Patients With Spontaneous Intracranial Hypotension

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to estimate the intracranial pressure (ICP, the pressure in your head) in subjects with intracranial hypotension (a condition caused by leakage of the fluid that surrounds your brain and spine) using non-invasive magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques, and to determine whether changes in estimated ICP are seen after treatment of this condition.

primary_outcome.measure: Intracranial pressure measurements estimated by the MRICP technique.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Approximately scan time will be 30 minutes

primary_outcome.measure: Cerebro spinal fluid pressure measured by lumbar puncture

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Intracranial pressure estimated with MR technique
Change in caliber to the transverse venous sinus caliber
Change in flow velocity through the transverse dural venous sinus

intervention.description: MRI sequences have been developed that may be able to estimate intracranial pressure in a non-invasive fashion
Lumbar puncture according to the standard-of-care treatment plan.
Epidural patching will be performed to the standard-of -care treatment plan

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Known diagnosis of intracranial hypotension, established by the following criteria: the presence of orthostatic headache, and one or more of the following criteria: prior CSF opening pressure â‰¤6 cmH20, demonstration of an active spinal CSF leak on prior spine imaging, or cranial MRI changes of intracranial hypotension.15
- Ability to provide informed consent.
- Expected ability to complete standard-of-care procedures (lumbar puncture and epidural patching)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Known contraindication to MRI (pacemaker, MRI incompatible hardware, etc.)
- Severe claustrophobia or other condition requiring the need for anxiolysis, sedation, or any other medication for MRI scanning
- Inability or expected inability to complete study interventions as scheduled
- Any known contraindication to standard-of-care procedures (e.g. coagulopathy, allergic reaction to required medication, lack of vascular access, etc.)
